We're going back to the moon, and we're going to need to train Astronauts how to land. This video is the result of trying to understand that control problem better. in the next video of this series, I'll show you footage from an actual NASA Lunar Lander software test I participated in many years ago.

Also, I'd like to say express grateful I am to everyone who supports Smarter Every Day on Patreon at https://www.patreon.com/smartereveryday . If you've never considered being a Patreon of Smarter Every Day, then feel free to click the link if you'd like to see what it's all about. If not, then no big deal! I'm grateful that you're here.

Great channel and content. A slight correction. We are not being pulled towards the earth at 9,8 metres/sec. The surface of the earth is accelerating up in all directions at 9,8 metres/second while being counter balanced, sort of speak, by the curvature in space-time. This is the true nature of gravity. We don't understand it fully but it is NOT a force.

NASA has chosen the Human Lander System (HLS) for the Artemis program and it's a version of the SpaceX Starship. This is 50 meters tall and much more massive than the Apollo LM. SpaceX has excellent autonomous systems on its Dragon spacecraft for docking to the ISS and Falcon 9 for landing. The F9 landing is crazy, it's on a drone ship deck heaving in 3 dimensions, those are impressive algorithms. Considering the size of the Starship HLS idk if real-time direct human control is possible. Possibly some kind of indirect synthetic control can be used. SpaceX will certainly build it to have a fully autonomous landing capability.

Armstrong has that Mickey Mouse voice because the film was shot at 24 frames per second, but played at 30 frames per second in order to be converted to the US TV standard.
The voice on that 16 mm film is recorded optically at the side of the frames, so it is played much faster than intended, raising the pitch of the voice...

You would think they would build a computer-based flight simulator, and program in the flight characteristics of the actual lunar lander and expected environmental conditions. An astronaut could do way more training, without risk to himself (herself?) and without losing any vehicles along the way. Perhaps engineers might need to build an LLTV, for use in the final stages of training. But I'm hard-pressed to believe that any vehicle they could build wouldn't be subject to erroneous factors (like wind resistance) that they could program out of the virtual environment.

I think it is far to assume that any future lunar landings will be 100% automated.

Granted pilots will need some form of training for emergency situations but I believe human intervention will be a last resort.

In science, if you could not consistently repeat, you might want to ask WHY. The argument of "it costs too much to go to moon" is bogus. That is the biggest deal for mankind to be on the moon and for deep space exploration. It is the biggest propaganda vehicle for US. But no, it "lost interest" and "locked up all the researches" and "lost the data" and "now try to figure out how to do the same thing they did in 1960s, with the technologies of 2020!"

Think with logic. This is NOT how humanity and science progress. So stop the BS!
Are NASA employees allowed to just come on a show like this or do they have to go through public relations?

Stop the BS. With our technological and historical perspective, if we do not realize it is fake, we are just being pretentious. First, in the age of bulky diode tubes, how could that little landing module engages in REAL TIME SIGNAL PROCESSING for sending massive data from moon to moon orbit to earth? Do you know that in this time and age where Integrated Circuit could fit billions of transistors in a circuit board, our signal processing from deep space is still very sluggish at best. The moon landers and mars landers are at best sending out pictures and we just stick them together for viewing. And in 1960s, with nothing but diode tubes, we managed to have extensive REAL TIME BROACASTING from moon surface.

Second, the moon is still having 1/6 of the earth gravity. It is almost impossible to jam pack enough explosive onto a LANDING MOON MODULE, so it could shoot the heavy, life supporting ascending module back to the 300 miles up moon orbit.

Third, by the end of the moon landing era, the success rate was so high that astronauts were playing golfs and having moon rover car chase. It is almost like a walk in the backyard. And then out of nowhere, with such an advanced technology that shine through history, it is shut down. Like nothing happened. And the technology is gone! This is totally contradicting to how technology and history works. If US have such an advanced technology, it would have land on the moon once a decade to assert its domination on the world. The cost is really small compared to the propaganda costs in any form and shape! Nope! It is shut down. The technology is lost and we are back to square one!

Go figure!

You are one smart dude, there is no doubt, and I love your videos. You posses a very down to earth way of explaining topics that is very appealing. But, I want to offer some friendly advice on the use of the phrase "for free". You cannot give or get something "for free". Inserting the word "for" implies that you have something called "free" that you can give or get in exchange for something. So, first you have to give or get something called "free" before the transaction can take place. Can't be done. The proper way to phrase it would be to simply say "I'm giving you something "free". It's proper and it sounds correct, because it is. Growing up in a family full of teachers has made it impossible for me to let this egregious misuse of the phrase impossible to ignore. However, nearly everyone misuses it, so don't feel too bad. :-}

What actually happens on the moon landing(s) low-key confirmed by his guest Ben Feist is that the Apollo Guidance Computer (AGC) does all of the flying until final approach where Armstrong and other astronauts use the rate-of-decent  mode (P66),  a mode not unlike drones for the home market where the stabilization is handled by the AGC and Neil uses the fly by wire stick to control horizontal velocity, avoid a boulder field and then bring bring the horizontal velocity to zero; another two switches can speed up or slow down the computers rate of descent in increments of one foot per second.  I know the LLTV also had a computer. How similar was it's stabilization and controls to the actual LEM and the AGC's P66?

I flew a  test device in Grumman hangar 5 over a mosaic set of lunar photos. All I had was a mockup of the LM cockpit. I made 3 test landing attempts for evaluation data.  50 years later I toured the hangar at the Cape Canaveral facility and in an alcove next to the Saturn V rocket was the same unit I tested at the Grumman facility. I worked at Grumman for 30+ years on the A-6 Intruder , the F-14 Tomcat,and The JSTARS .  Fun years!

Another reason why people suspect it is fake is because in 1960s, there were no integrated circuits.  All computation was using vacuum tubes.  There is no way that they could fit that many vacuum tubes into that small module to achieve the REAL TIME SIGNAL PROCESSING FOR LIVE BROADCASTING.  Once you realize it is physically impossible with 1960s technologies, you will realize the truth.  Hard science won't lie.

Landing is relatively easy.  Launching the heavy life support module back up to 300 miles orbit is hard, even with 1/6 gravity.  That is the real reason why people suspect the US landing and returning are fake.  If you have a chance to look at the return rocket combustion video, you will conclude it was a joke.

Hi Dustin. Of all Smarter Everyday videos you have ever done so far or at least that I have seen, this one is my favorite if not the most meaningful. It was so special getting to talk to Wayne Otteinger (I hope I spell his name right). The fruits of so such R&D in the form of knowledge, understanding and comprehension of the why and wherefore that came at such a high cost of patience, perseverance, time, energy, etc., has been taken from us by NASA and by government in so many ways ranging from no longer pursuing the goals within our reach, to dumbing down the general level of intellect in our society. Mr. Otteinger I'm sure answered honestly when he said that engineers of his generation weren't better than ours, but I still disagree with him on that point. Certainly scientists of his generation were better. If scientists and engineers today didn't have the shoulders of Mr. Otteinger's generation to stand on, if our generation had to start off from zero knowledge of astrophysics and had only the same tools that his generation had (e.g. no Matlab, no Solidworks, etc.), our generation would not have the low-level problem solving dexterity, the patience, the perseverance, the dedication, and the ability to see monumental challenges as a series of simple fundamental mathematical measurements and  problems be solved. If finding the answer isn't as simple as taking the variables and entering them into a computer to be modeled and simulated I have my doubts whether or not scientists and engineers of our era would be ready and able to solve those problems with mere pencil, paper, slide rule, and classical applied engineering. We would get tired of trying, throw up our hands and find something "more interesting" to do like play stupid video games. The brain drain here in the western world (which I could write for hours about) is perhaps the greatest casualty and tragedy of what has happened to us as a society.

Kerbal Space Program models that problem very well! I've had a few mishaps over the years that were the result of touching down sideways while I was trying to get rid of the horizontal velocity that I had underestimated. The ingame equivalent to Venus, which is called "Eve" has a very small moon named "Gilly" which has such low gravity that ur almost better off using something to hold on to the surface after touchdown rather than just letting ur lander stand on its landing gear. Every maneuver u perform in its SOI has to be performed with utmost precision or u'll end up over- or undershooting stuff big time real quick! Also, due to its small size and low gravity it's not a spherical body, but looks more like a huge asteroid.

All these things combined once led to a crash landing where Gilly had rotated far enough to no longer present the same surface at the same angle and my impatience had led to me time-warping beyond the point where I would've needed to fire up my really wimpy engine to slow down enough for touchdown, so I had to change my trajectory dramatically to avoid crashing into the surface, leading to 1 of the situations I described in the first sentence. Fortunately I managed to slow down enough before touchdown that nothing broke from the impact but I still landed sideways. But thanks to Gilly's low gravity I could use the RCS to just barely get the thing upright.

I had the honor of meeting one of the engineers who participated in the Apollo program in his home. This was just after the Tom Hanks "Apollo 13" movie was released, and we spoke of the enormous challenges that the ground team faced during the Apollo 13 crisis. I asked him about the scene in the movie where the engineering team had to design a CO2 scrubber from available components on the spacecraft. He said it happened pretty much like it was portrayed in the movie except that the team was not surprised ... they had intimate knowledge of all the parts available, and they had prepared for similar contingencies. He said that it was still a huge amount of pressure, but the team was the cream of the crop, and they came through. They had the Right Stuff!

Here's the deal... early astronauts were airplane jockeys, and didn't want to just ride an automatic rocket... at all times, the Saturn V was able to be manually controlled by a joystick at the pilot's side.  That philosophy died a well-deserved death... computers do a much better job of figuring out physics than we do.  All Apollo LM pilots took over the controls at the very end, landing the crafts manually... but there was no need to... they could have designated the spot and the system would have landed the LM automatically.  We repeatedly land craft on the Moon and Mars automatically... what is the difference when a human is on board?  Well... if they're a pilot, they want control... that ends up being the whole deal.

Hey, excellent video and content! This is one of those very important videos to humanity.
I wanted to share I was fortunate enough to meet one of the engineers, Henry Olynik, who worked for Grumman when they won the LEM project. He helped to work on designing the landing gear for the moon's powdery surface. HIS FINGERPRINTS ARE ON THE LUNAR LANDER! He even has work on milling titanium alloys published in a textbook from 1964! Also, just throwing it in for recognition he was the US Blind Chess Champion in 1999! Due to old age, his mind is deteriorating. The "shoulders from which to build upon" are getting weaker with time. I salute you, Destin, for making videos like this in an attempt to preserve this critical knowledge. I always wanted to do something like a Q&A with him. However, due to a barrier of knowledge on my behalf, other than the basic textbook stuff one could find themselves there was no way I could have ever picked at his brain to "unlock the secrets" like you did to Mr. Ottinger.

Trust me, I share your excitement of being in the presence of, recognized and spoken to by someone with such honor.

Thank you for this.

Sincerely,

Audio Quality: At times I really struggled to understand the man you were interviewing because of the audio quality and connection, and I'm a native English speaker. Can I suggest that you record the audio at better quality? You are presumably relying on something like Zoom or Skype, which can produce very poor quality when the connection is poor. You could ask the person to simply record the audio on their computer at the same time, or with their mobile phone's voice recorder app, and then send you the file afterwards, which would be far better quality. It would certainly reduce the cognitive load of the listener.

It's especially a shame with something like this where your interview could become part of long-term archive interview footage but millions of people will struggle to understand parts, especially non-Americans and non-native speakers. And it's so easy to fix! Personally I would also send the person a $20 tie-clip mic in the post beforehand but maybe that's excessive!

My few thoughts:
1. Manned missions are exciting in a very human way, people get happy that "we" did it, even if they personally did nothing (maybe except paying taxes to fund that), but they cost so much money. Robotic missions do so much more science for the same amount of money, and engineers are getting better at building robots - fast. And remote sensing gets better as well. In the times of Apollo program arguably humans were really needed to do science on site, not so much today.
2. If the Americans taxpayers decide to go for manned mission for achievement sake, better forget the Moon and go to Mars directly. It is a bit like climbing Mt. Everest - the first few climbers were huge success, later they had to create artificial achievements on top of that - without oxygen, in winter, naked... errr... the last one is still free to take. It has little sense to go to the Moon again, IMO.
3. Manned mission to Mars would do useful science - but IMO much more about human travel in space, which may be beneficial on a much, much longer timescale. As for planetary science, manned mission will explore one spot on Mars surface for a few weeks or months - for that amount of money it would be possible to send hundreds if not thousands robotic missions and explore that many spots of different geology (areology?) for years, and understand Mars much, much better.

BTW. thanks for the historical insight and great interview.

KSP LLTV is pretty close to get the feel for the inputs to be learned instinctively.  I wonder if a virtual reality, physics-accurate simulator would be enough to get the lltv experience. Only thing missing would be the lack of Gs, which is very important even in car racing. Someone who can race a rally in real life is lost in simulator because now he has to switch from judging cars momentum based on acceleration his body feels, to just purely visual analysis. But I think that someone who trained only on simulators, can still use the visual analysis just the same, and gradually understand how the g-forces relate to it. Or even just use the visual clues on their own.

"Velocity equaling zero upon touching the moon's surface" was neither necessary, wasn't design on the LEM, nor ever happened.  The legs had crush absorbers that anticipated some downward velocity (i.e. impact).  Mr. Armstrong did set it down so gently that little give happened; its why they had some difficulty getting back up the ladder while on following missions it wasn't a big problem.  As an example, Apollo 12's impact with the surface was significant enough there was actually some initial concern about damage because the legs had compressed to the maximum.

Everything today is computer-controlled and fly-by-wire. And you think that a pilot is going to be controlling final approach manually?

Yeah, I don't see that happening. In fact, I'd say it's 50/50 whether a pilot has the stick in his hand making that last decision about where to set it down. The major advantage that engineers now, compared to those in the 60's have, is AI design and supercomputing. Mathematical modelling and simulations can test, break and predict millions of scenarios long before a human grabs the joystick. We've landed vehicles on complicated far more distant celestial bodies successfully. The mars landers are good examples. Not only does Mars have less gravity than earth, it also has a volatile atmosphere in motion, communication dead zones and transmission lag. We have reusable rockets that land themselves on platforms. It fills me with great anticipation and excitement to see people once again reaching for the stars. What I am fearful of, is the social media mob squad who will fill the airwaves with rubbish opinions and complete inaccuracies as they bang on about the money waste on space exploration, whilst warming their drink in a microwave oven and browsing the internet on a hand held device...

The Board of Supervisors of Shenandoah, a county west of Washington D.C. in Virginia, passed a resolution on January 12 to call for an end to the forced organ harvesting in China.

The resolution indicated that evidence has shown the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) has murdered a large number of prisoners of conscience, such as Falun Gong practitioners, and sold their organs for profit. This crime still continues.

Below is full text of the resolution.

To educate Shenandoah’s residents and medical community on the risks of traveling to China for organ Transplant in light of recent reports of state-sponsored organ harvesting from prisoners of conscience.

Whereas, extensive and credible reports have revealed mass killing of prisoners of conscience in the People’s Republic of China, primarily practitioners of the Chinese spiritual practice of Falun Gong, but also other religions and ethnic minority groups, in order to obtain organs for transplantation; and

Whereas, The China Tribunal, an independent tribunal sitting in London chaired by Sir Geoffrey Nice QC, who was a prosecutor at the international criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, concluded on June 18, 2019, in a unanimous determination at the end of its year long hearings, that the killing of detainees in China for organ harvesting is continuing and victims include imprisoned followers of the Falun Gong movement; and

Whereas, the 2017 Freedom House Report, “The Battle for China’s Spirit”, states that “available evidence suggests that forced extraction of organs from Falun Gong detainees for sale in transplant operations has occurred on a large scale and may be continuing;” and

Whereas, an investigative report published in June 2016 by human rights attorney David Matas, former Canadian Secretary of State for Asia-Pacific, David Kilgour, and journalist Ethan Gutmann, estimated that China is performing transplants at a rate amounting to “an industrial-scale, state-directed organ transplantation system, controlled through national policies and funding, and implicating both the military and civilian healthcare systems”, as Kilgour described these practices in his speech to the European Parliament in 2016; and

Whereas, Falun Gong, a spiritual practice involving meditative “qigong” exercises and centered on the values of truthfulness, compassion, and forbearance, became immensely popular in China in the late 1990s with multiple estimates placing the number of practitioners at upwards of seventy million (70,000,000); and

Whereas, in July 1999, the Chinese Communist Party launched an intensive, nationwide persecution designed to eradicate the spiritual practice of Falun Gong. Hundreds of thousands of Falun Gong practitioners have been detained illegally in Chinese reeducation-through-labor camps, detention centers, and prisons, where physical and mental torture is common.

Whereas, in June 2016, the United States House of Representatives unanimously passed House Resolution 343, condemning the systemic, state-sanctioned organ harvesting from practitioners of Falun Gong and other prisoners of conscience; and

I really enjoyed watching this video. My dad worked on the Lunar Module Simulators (both the one at the Cape and the one here in Houston), so I knew quite a bit about their role. I knew very little about these machines and figured they were failures, but I am surprised to see how valuable they really were. My dad went on to work on Apollo Soyuz, Skylab and Space Shuttle. My sister got an unrelated job at NASA and ended up working in the same department as my dad. She still works there today in a support role for the ISS. My dad is retired and will be 81 this month.

I write short stories, and I'm curious about something.... Given the Zero-Velocity-necessary condition, would that apply to someone who time-travels such as in the H.G. Well's book The Time Machine. Is there something to take into account if someone where to time-travel? In that story, the professor time-travels in one spot supposedly never leaving his geographic spot. Nowhere does the story account for what takes place upon ending the time-travel. Given that speed is defined as distance over time, and given that the Earth is rotating at about 1,000  miles per hour; would a person coming out of a time-travel  have to Speed-Up to 1,000 miles an hour in order to touch the surface of the Earth; otherwise, wouldn't that person have the relative effect of trying to hop onto a treadmill that is moving at 1,000 miles an hour when his or her current speed is no longer defined because he or she time traveled ?  Speed = distance / time ... and their time is not defined... I've had this question for a long time and want to incorporate this fact into another one of my short stories.

"Carrying the Fire" is, IMO, the best of the astronaut bios, and the Apollo In Real Time website is a scientific and technical treasure. I hope it's preserved for all time. A thing to keep in mind about the descent of the lunar module was that it was largely controlled by onboard software. Neil Armstrong took over control toward the end when it turned out the computer was taking them toward a field of boulders, but otherwise the landing could have been automatic, and I believe most of the other landings were. This is not to take anything away from the astronauts' capabilities - Neil was at his test pilot best that day, and every mission has stories where nerves of steel were required! I just picked up "Sunburst and Luminary", which is the story of the writing of that control software. (Geek alert!) Can't wait for the rest of this series!

My father John W. was the IBM DDAS Telemetry Network Launch Controller in the Firing Room in the LCC at KSC for Apollo 10, 11, 12, 16, 17 and Skylab 2, 3, and 4. He knew Wernher von Braun and Alan Shepard among others. He has a 1 second appearance in Firing Room 1 in the documentary film "Apollo 11".

Dad was actually in the Firing Room for both the First Humans sent to the Moon and the "Last" Humans sent to the Moon.

The word "last" is hard to say out loud! It will have been more than Half a Century before "last" is erased! So sad!

After Skylab ended Dad transferred to IBM Owego NY were he built Space Shuttle Flight Computer boards , a program ran by the father of NASA / SpaceX Astronaut Doug Hurley. Dad helped build Challenger's Fight Computers and our family got to watch her maiden flight STS-6 from on base which was the best experience ever, other than watching Skylab launched on a Saturn V from on base!!!! Designing and building public Space Stations was a life long passion of mine so I applied and was accepted into "Rocket Science" school just south of KSC with co-ops lined up.

Shortly after getting my acceptance letter to space science college, 35 years ago this past week, Challenger exploded due to human error. Later that year her Flight Computer boards were returned to the Dad's IBM Owego's Core Memory lab in a tank of deionized water for forensics. We were all devastated. The aerospace industry tanked . I made an educated choice to switch majors to EE and CS Engineering. The Dream was Gone!

Space industry families have a lot of ups and downs. Dad's experiences with Apollo, Skylab and the Shuttle are the backstory to a grand sci-fi trilogy in development ( "Project Mercury Trilogy") revolving around those that actually made the right stuff happen and the reason we have not returned to the Moon!

More info on Dad's experiences during the Apollo era @ProjectApolloFilm

I have watched the video of the LLTV when Neil ejects several times, but I never noticed that the jet engine was gimballed!

Yay! The flying bedstead. It's the absolute favourite of mine, of all the training equipment that was used in the Apollo programme. Neil was never blamed for punching out as far as I know, but this is the first time I heard the real reason for the incident. I knew it was because Neil had lost the ability to control the attitude of the craft, but did NOT know that it was because he'd been allowed to run out of oxidiser pressure. I'd always assumed it was a purely control (computer/electronic) issue.

Mr Ottinger is also being very gracious about modern engineers, but I have to say they did things in those days with so very little and they made it work. I'm truly in awe because things that we take for granted now were extremely difficult and cost millions if not billions of dollars back then. For example the AGC was essentially a four bit computer that was cutting edge technology at the time. I'm pretty sure that a 2021 16 bit microcontroller which you can buy today for about $2 with a clock speed of 16MHz (as opposed to 1MHz) is actually far more powerful and has several hundred times more RAM. (they had 2000 four bit words, or about 1KB in modern terms).
I'm not sure in 2021 that very many modern software engineers could deal with those sorts of limitations. Modern programmers dream in their main programming language (Yes, this is from personal experience) but REAL programmers dream in machine code. 6c 65 67 65 6e 64 61 72 79 20 65 6e 67 69 6e 65 65 72 73

The Russian moon program was quite different, due to the lack of high specific impulse engines (they were all kerosene-based in all N1 stages, unlike hydrogen-powered engines of Saturn V), which limited their design. One of the limitations was that the transfer to and from the LM would require an EV, and only one person would actually land on the moon.

It would be quite interesting whether they did an evaluation of the LM simulator issue, or whether they never reached that far in the project stages when it was finally cancelled.

imposing restrictions on an artist does not make their art worse. Restrictions are what gives an artist inspiration, and a starting point. Some of the most beautiful art was created with the help of restrictions, whether it was the medium of the art, the tools available, or even problems held by the person creating it.

engineers back in the 60s had limited resources, and it was those very limitations that allowed them to recognize what problems needed to be solved, and pushed them to find unique ways to solve them. It's easy to see modern engineers as spoiled and much less innovative than older engineers, but that's because modern engineers have too many tools to help them solve problems. It's easy to get lost and hesitate to do something when you can't pick a direction to go to get it done. Imagine being in an open, flat plane, versus going down a thin pathway.

It's not that modern engineers aren't as creative, it's that there's much fewer things to be creative ABOUT. so many paths have already been mapped out for them, it's harder to find a new path that no-one has gone down. It's not impossible, but it's much harder.

I'm a glider pilot (in training) from NZ and I've watched your previous video on winch launching a glider in Germany a few years ago (it's great fun from the pilots seat!) I've often thought that a lesser known but immensely fascinating aspect of gliding is mountain wave soaring, where gliders can use the rising air in the standing waves that form in the atmosphere in the lee of mountains in strong wind conditions. Learning to fly in wave conditions is a great example for me that knowledge =/= understanding, since it's all very well to know that air will be going up or down in a certain place based on clouds and other indicators but the complete understanding of why the air behaves like it does is less tangible. You might have heard of the Perlan Project, which reached around 76,000ft of altitude using these waves in South America. Usually we don't fly that high...

I think it's a phenomenon which deserves a video - and it is laminar flow too! Laminar flow is awesome :)

AMAZING video!!! I was working at Edwards AFB in 2014, took a tour of the Armstrong flight research center and our tour guide (an employee of the model shop) took us to an unremarkable garage door. He opened the garage door and to my amazement sat a LLRV...just sitting there. None of my friends had an idea what they were looking at, but I immediately was overjoyed with the artifact that sat before us. That is a day that I will never forget. It is a day that I saw history sitting before me quietly behind a garage door in the middle of the desert. It is my understanding that the LLRV has since been moved to a proper museum.

Future lunar landers are definitely an interesting subject. On Apollo programme you basically always landed with a human on the helm because the sole cargo to be landed was the human itself and other instrument that they took with them. If sustained lunar surface presence were to be maintained in the future unmanned landers are going to be needed, and they'd most likely be either partially autonomous (having separate controls for certain parts of the landing) or fully autonomous (say, can actually work if there's a boulder underneath and decide that it's not a good idea to land there).

NASA and other partners in the Artemis programme is working on fully autonomous landing system, also the current commercial HLV programme requires a demonstration for the selected design that will land autonomously on the Moon. I will say that a backup manual control would always be welcome, however...

Absolutely loved this video!  I'm a bit of an aviation nerd so I can add a couple of minor notes here; perhaps the most famous VTOL aircraft of all is the Harrier which first flew in 1967. This was preceded by a couple of prototypes made by the same company (Hawker Aviation, if you're interested) the first of which, the P.1127 first flew in November 1960. Predating that though was the Short SC.1 which had it's first VTOL flight in May 1958 (the Bell X-14's first flight was in February 1957).  VTOL flight has been around for a lot longer than we think.

"Do you think that engineers in the 50s and 60s were better than engineers today?"

As a software engineer, I'd say "it depends". Not inherently better, but because engineers thrive when they have funding and a vision and can experiment and build with few distractions, but it's rare that all those pieces come together in one program at one time. Engineers working on many aspects of the space program worked in such an environment, and so I would say that a good engineer from such a program would probably be a better engineer than most engineers today who don't work in such an environment. But take engineers with funding who are dedicated to a vision and have leadership who will move mountains of money to clear a path for them to work (see SpaceX), and they can design and build even more amazing machines today than could be built in the 50s and 60s. Consider that we've grown so used to SpaceX's VTOL rockets that we're starting to think of it as normal. Progress!

Another fantastic video. As an engineer, I wonder if the average viewer could follow along with some of the technical jargon. But essentially the jet engines rotating components that allow it to produce thrust, would essentially cause the LLTV to spin around. (This is why helicopters have that smaller rotor on a long boom). So they took some of the jet engine pressure and routed it to nozzles to counteract that rotational inertia. A clever and efficient use of fuel. And so impressive that this was all done without modern digital systems controls, PIDs, etc.

The question there at the end about engineering is really interesting.

I think in one sense an engineer’s “task” is definitely easier now, because you can make iterations of your solution more or less instantly in software.

But, with that, one of the most difficult aspects of engineering is being able to decide which “department” to fix a problem in. Now, that problem is many times more complex. Sure, you CAN write a software patch. But should you really be fixing the hardware side? That decision is every bit as much “engineering” as the actual solution itself

I was collaborating with the ERPS in the mid 2000's back when John Carmack was a member and built Armadillo Aerospace with a handful of ERPS members and engineers. One of their first projects was a lunar lander / hopper to compete for the Ansari X-prize where much of the early engineering was open sourced with ERPS members and others on forums and groups. While the 1/6th gravity simulation was never really solved, (I believe armadillo used a crane with a tension spool), I had honestly never thought about that particular problem prior to that project, and it really affected me, left me awestruck at engineering challenges they overcame 50 years prior, just for the lander itself, let alone the 50 million other challenges involved with putting humans on the moon and bringing them back alive.

We look back at history's greatest feats of engineering and usually tge focus falls to the great pyramids, modern skyscrapers, the 3 gorges dam, etc, but by far, if you really look at all of the previously unknown challenges that were solved, technologies that had to be invented as part of the process, putting people on the moon was by far, the greatest feat of engineering in human history, probably multiple orders of magnitude more complicated than the next feat beneath it, and I doubt we'll ever have to do something as complicated without the prior engineering experience again.

When people refer to them as the greatest generation, it isn't hyperbole... I genuinely believe that ONLY the generation that grew out of out-fighting, out-engineering, out-producing and beating the axis powers in WW2 could have saw something so impossible as putting a man on the moon in 8 years when we had only just managed to launch a man into suborbital flight, as not only feasible, but they actually did it.

LOL.....training?   Ha!     "outer" space is a vacuum of negative 17 torr.    Now that is more powerful than you can imagine, much more.   Rockets cannot work in outer space as the vacuum not only would give the rocket nothing which it can push to get forward momentum (no air like rockets, airplanes and balloons use) but the vacuum is so strong it would pull the fuel and oxidizer right through the seals.  No material natural or man made can withstand that kind of vacuum as any.....ANY....internal pressure, no matter how small would immediately, catastrophically cause the seal to rupture and immediately explode like an over filled balloon does with the last breath blown into it.

NASA uses similar technology to this to train astronauts in zero-g. They have a machine called ARGOS (Active Response Gravity Offload System) in Houston which offloads the weight of the astronaut, and then translates any forces they apply (pushing off of objects) into a sideways force which is maintained by the system. It's essentially a more complex version of what they did for the landers but in all directions. I had a chance to try it out as part of some work my company was doing and it was a highlight of my life.  If you can, you should contact them and make a video as it was extremely cool.
